body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

@IISResetMe pointed me to this a while back; while it may not often arise, the inconsistency is problematic.

The short of it: Explicit coercion is _always_ attempted in _named_ parameter binding, but only _if needed_ in _positional_ binding [source code link](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/ParameterBinderController.cs#L1286), which can unexpectedly result in different behavior.

The following repro is contrived, because  _doubly_ type-constraining a parameter is pointless (and should arguably be prevented at parse time), but a real-world case that _may_ have the same cause (I cannot personally verify it, including whether it also affects PS _Core_) is [this COM+PIA-related Stack Overflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/72669319/45375).

```powershell
# Sample function with (contrived) double type constraint: [int] first, then [string]
function foo { param( [string] [int] $p); $p }

# POSITIONAL: OK, because *only [string]*, the leftmost type constraint is honored.
foo 'aha'
 
# NAMED: !! BREAKS, because [int] is honored first, and 'aha' cannot be converted to [int]
foo -p 'aha' 
```



### Expected behavior

(Leaving aside whether double type constraints should be allowed) both `foo` calls should fail.


### Actual behavior

The positional-binding call succeeds, whereas the named-binding one fails with:
`foo: Cannot process argument transformation on parameter 'p'. Cannot convert value "aha" to type "System.Int32". Error: "Input string was not in a correct format."`


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.4
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The issue is new and needs to be triaged by a work group.
labels.name: Needs-Triage

### Steps to reproduce

Using V7 takes considerably longer that V5 and it does not return the same results. 

[GetDLLTest.zip](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/8929138/GetDLLTest.zip)

In the zip file execute the Get-Dll-Test.ps1 script on both V5 and V7 and note the time differences and the number of items returned.

To compare the contents of the returned data the results are exported via export-clixml which does take a while - be patient.

When you have both the V5 and V7 xml files you can run Get-Dll-Test.ps1 to see the differences.

I was trying to find the most efficient way to execute a similar command on a number of files and the best way to see timing differences is to have a large number as this shows what if any improvements can be made by changing the way you approach the issue at hand. The commented-out code was going to be addressed next, but I thought I would report this first.

91 items not returned in V7 and it is slower by 2 minutes

body:
This PR adds a new pwsh command line parameter to enable the display of the profile load time message.

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Changes the host to not display the profile load time by default.  A new pwsh command line switch `-ShowProfileLoadTime` was added to allow someone to show the profile load time regardless of the length of the load time.

```
Usage: pwsh[.exe] [-Login] [[-File] <filePath> [args]]
                  [-Command { - | <script-block> [-args <arg-array>]
                                | <string> [<CommandParameters>] } ]
                  [-ConfigurationName <string>] [-CustomPipeName <string>]
                  [-EncodedCommand <Base64EncodedCommand>]
                  [-ExecutionPolicy <ExecutionPolicy>] [-InputFormat {Text | XML}]
                  [-Interactive] [-MTA] [-NoExit] [-NoLogo] [-NonInteractive] [-NoProfile]
                  [-OutputFormat {Text | XML}] [-SettingsFile <filePath>] [-ShowProfileLoadTime]
                  [-SSHServerMode] [-STA] [-Version] [-WindowStyle <style>]
                  [-WorkingDirectory <directoryPath>]

       pwsh[.exe] -h | -Help | -? | /?
       
...

-ShowProfileLoadTime

    Displays the time taken to load the PowerShell profiles.

-SSHServerMode | -sshs
```

## PR Context

Addresses #16929 to further reduce the amount of default startup banner text.

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open a new PowerShell terminal with (`pwsh.exe`) or without a profile (`pwsh.exe -NoProfile`).
2. Write any command, for example `cd .`
3. Select all or part of the command, for example with `Ctrl+A` or `Shift+←`.
4. Run the command with `Enter`.

### Expected behavior

```console
The command is deselected and executed.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The command is executed, but retains the selection styling.
```

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

The `-Header` parameter of the `Import-Csv` and `ConvertFrom-Csv` lets a user load data from **headerless** Csv files but there is actually no convenient way to convert or export the data back to a **headerless** Csv file or string.
The workaround is using the `Select-Object` cmdlet and skip the first line, e.g.:

```PowerShell
Import-Csv .\input.csv -Header 1..9 | ... |ConvertTo-Csv |Select-Object -Skip 1 |Set-Content -Path .\Output.csv
```
See e.g.: [Powershell export-csv with no headers?](https://stackoverflow.com/a/26390115/1701026)  
and: [Slowness to Remove 3,7 and 9 column from | separated txt file using PowerShell](https://stackoverflow.com/a/72627605/1701026)

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

It would be nice to be able to simply do this:

```PowerShell
Import-Csv .\input.csv -Header 1..9 | ... |Export-Csv .\Output.csv -NoHeader
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: This is an edge case, given that "number string" property names such as `101` are rare, but the bug is quite insidious in its subtlety.

Credit goes to @jhoneill for discovering the bug, including [how to reproduce it](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/17520#issuecomment-1154527363)

In short: If a given integer, say `.101`, is used to access a _property_ of a custom object in a session _before_ using `.101` on a _hashtable_ that has an entry with such an `[int]`-typed key, the latter access fails _for the remainder of the session_ (only _index syntax_ (`[101]`) works consistently). If the order is reversed (hashtable access first in the session), everything works as expected.

```powershell
# Define hashtable with numeric key..,
$h = [hashtable]@{ 101 = 'foo' }
# ...and an equivalent [pscustomobject], 
#    where the number implicitly becomes a property-name *string*.
#    Note that the numbers must be the *same* to surface the bug.
$o = [pscustomobject]@{ 101 = 'foo' }

# === These always works as expected: property access on the object, index access on the hastable.
# !! If you comment out the next line and re-run the code *in a new session*, the symptom goes away.
[pscustomobject] @{ object = 'pscustomobject'; access='.101'; value = $o.101 }
[pscustomobject] @{ object = 'hashtable'; access='[101]'; value = $null -eq $h[101] ? '$null' : $h[101] }

# === !! These *normally* work, but stop working for the remainder of the session, regardless of scope,
#     !! if `$o.101` was executed *first* in the session.
[pscustomobject] @{ object = 'hashtable'; access='.101'; value = $null -eq $h.101 ? '$null' : $h.101 }
[pscustomobject] @{ object = 'hashtable'; access='.([int] 101)'; value = $null -eq $h.([int] 101) ? '$null' : $h.([int] 101) }
```


### Expected behavior

```console
object         access       value
------         ------       -----
pscustomobject .101         foo
hashtable      [101]        foo
hashtable      .101         foo
hashtable      .([int] 101) foo
```


### Actual behavior

```console
object         access       value
------         ------       -----
pscustomobject .101         foo
hashtable      [101]        foo
hashtable      .101         $null  # !!
hashtable      .([int] 101) $null  # !!
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.4
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

When outputting UTF-8 from a native application PowerShell pipes fail to parse the data correctly even if a BOM is present. 
In contrast this works in PowerShell 5.1 - that's why I'm reporting this as a bug.

The following python script will produce UTF-8 encoded output with a BOM.

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import sys
sys.stdout.buffer.write("äöüß αβγδ\n".encode("utf_8_sig"))
```

Powershell 5.1 is able to recognise the output is UTF-8 encoded if the BOM is present. PowerShell 7.2.4 does not. 

Note that both shells were started with the `-noprofile` option to ensure default configuration.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> python .\test.py | echo
äöüß αβγδ
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS > python .\test.py | echo
´╗┐├ñ├Â├╝├ƒ ╬▒╬▓╬│╬┤
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Undoubtedly an edge case, but it makes me wonder whether other discrepancies between single-object dot notation (property access) and member-enumeration-based dot notation exist:

```powershell
@{ 42 = 'foo' }.42           # OK -> 'foo'

(@{ 42 = 'foo1' }, @{ 42 = 'foo2' }).42  -join ', ' # !! No output
```

Note that  the problem does _not_ occur with _string_-valued hashtable keys (which is what's typical), e.g. 
`(@{ a42 = 'foo1' }, @{ a42 = 'foo2' }).a42  -join ', '`
Similarly, the following works as expected:
`([pscustomobject] @{ 42 = 'foo1' }, [pscustomobject] @{ 42 = 'foo2' }).42  -join ', '`


### Expected behavior

```console
foo
foo1, foo2
```


### Actual behavior

```console
foo
```

_No response_

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.4
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: This is related to various other, similar bugs: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+%22parameter+parsing%2Fpassing%22

When using `pwsh -File` trying to pass a _positional_ argument that is a _negative number_ fails, because the `-` is apparently invariably interpreted as starting a parameter _name_:

```powershell
# Create sample script t.ps1
@'
[CmdletBinding()] param([int] $p) "-p value: $p"
'@ > t.ps1

pwsh -NoProfile -File t.ps1 -1     # !! BREAKS: *positional* argument
pwsh -NoProfile -File t.ps1 -p -1  # OK, as *named* argument.
./t.ps1 -1                         # OK, positional argument with *direct invocation*.
```

Note that quoting `-1` does _not_ help.

### Expected behavior

```console
-p value: -1
-p value: -1
-p value: -1
```


### Actual behavior

```console
t.ps1: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name '1'.
-p value: -1
-p value: -1
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core v7.3.0-preview.4
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: The reported behavior is by design.
labels.name: Resolution-By Design

### Steps to reproduce

Note:
* Arguably, as the (new) name of the feature suggests, member-access enumeration should only apply to the behavior of `.`, the member-access operator, not also to `[]`, the index operator. However, even though it is a distinct operator with its own name, it still _accesses a member_, namely the parameterized `Item` property that `[]` is syntactic sugar for.

* However, given that dictionaries can be accessed with either operator (e.g. `@{ foo = 1 }['foo']` or `@{ foo = 1 }.foo`, the non-support for `[]` on collections  makes for an awkward asymmetry:

```powershell
# Index notation with key:
(@{ foo = 1 }, @{ foo = 2 })['foo']  # !! NO OUTPUT

# Dot notation (property access):
(@{ foo = 1 }, @{ foo = 2 }).foo     # OK -> 1, 2
```


### Expected behavior

Both commands should produce the same output.


### Actual behavior

The first command (index notation with key) produces no output.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core v7.3.0-preview.4
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
For reference:
- Issue: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/17452
- PR that fixed the issue: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/17455

### Context summary

The previous behavior in 7.2.x is: `Out-File` and `Out-String` remove escape sequences from the passed-in strings when `$PSStyle.OutputRendering` is `Host` or `PlainText`.

There are some problems with this behavior, especially when having `Host` to be the default value for `$PSStyle.OutputRendering`. See https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/17455#issuecomment-1147680515 for the details of those problems.

Therefore, that behavior was changed by #17455 to be:
- when the input object is pure string, these 2 cmdlets keep the string input unchanged regardless of the `RenderingOutput` setting
- when the input object needs to have formatting views applied to it, these 2 cmdlets remove escape sequences from the formatting output strings based on the `RenderingOutput` setting, which is the same as the existing behavior.

### Recommendation from PowerShell Committee

The committee reviewed #17455 and recommended to add a new parameter to `Out-String` and `Out-File` to keep the previous behavior. Quote the comments https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/17455#pullrequestreview-1000516051 and https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/17455#issuecomment-1150521455 below:

> I think we should seriously consider adding a parameter to out-string and out-file which retains our current behavior. Perhaps a parameter `-AsPlainText` or some such will allow users to have the older behavior while we provide a safer default behavior.
>
> powershell-committee reviewed this, we would recommend adding a parameter to enable users to get back the previous behavior.
>

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Running PowerShell 7.2.4, I am performing a long running process in a WinRM Remote Session, some of the steps cause a brief network disruption that is handled gracefully in PowerShell 5.1 by trying to reconnect for 5 minutes, succeeding, and then carrying on with the rest of the process.

In PowerShell 7.2.4 this recovery process starts, but just as it recovers a null reference exception is thrown from the ProgressPane.Hide() function. this is unhandled and causes the pwsh process to exit.

I haven't had the opportunity to produce a minimal repo to reproduce this, I have however debugged this myself using the 7.2.4 tagged commit in the PowerShell repo. The exception is thrown on Line 179 of the ProgressPane.cs file which suggests that `_savedRegion` is null, this suggests there is some sort of threading issue.

I have Implemented a fix locally that adds lock statements to ProgressPane.Hide() and ProgressPane.Show() functions which resolves the issue. However I'm not sure if that fix would be acceptable for the project. I will link the PR here shortly.

### Expected behavior

```console
Recover from network interruption in remote sessions and continue processing.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Null reference exception while recovering causing process to terminate.
```


### Error details

_No response_

# PR Summary
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/2337
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13204
There were a lot of different ideas posted in this thread, and this is just my own personal preference/idea on how to solve this.  
I am open to other ideas if that's what the team/community wants.

You can add as many `@` signs as you want to the here-string, if you add 2 or more `@` signs you allow the string terminator to be indented like this:
```
Write-Host @@'
    Hello world!

        Here-strings are cool
    '@@
```
The line with the fewest leading whitespaces (not including empty lines) dictate how many whitespace characters are removed from each line so in the previous example the first line would have no spaces, and the third would have 4 spaces.

Single line here-strings are also supported: `Write-Host @'Hello world!'@` like the multi-line variant you can add as many `@` signs as you want.

There are 3 reasons why I picked multiple `@` signs over multiple `'` .  
1: It's easier to visually easier to see/count if you write `@@@@@'` VS `@'''''` especially when you also consider double quotes and all the different single/double quote variants that are also supported.  
2: If you decide to swap between a single quote and double quote here-string it's easier to just change 1 character in each end instead of multiple characters in each end.  
3: In the case of single line strings it allows the string to start with any character. It quotes were used you wouldn't be able to start the string with a quote character because it would be counted as part of the "header" section of the here-string.


<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context
It's annoying to not be able to match the surrounding indentation if you for example use a herestring inside a function. Even if the content doesn't care about the leading whitespace the string terminator does so you end up with an ugly little `'@` if you try to indent all the code that can be indented.  
Sometimes when writing string filters you end up needing to quote values inside the string which means you either need to remember to escape or use the opposite quotes. It's nicer to just start a filter with @' or @" and no longer worry about having to escape characters inside the string.
<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

## PR Checklist

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a Powershell Tool designer I want a command like Start/Stop-Transcript that will capture verbose output but not display it to the console So that the user of the tool gets an easy to consume minimal console experience but there is a detailed log available in case of problems with tools that run for longer than 10 mins or if the issue is not easily reproducable.

Today it seems that we either need to roll our own centralised complex logging routines or highly decorated contents of our scripts using redirection operators (something like ```Tee-Object 'filename' 4>$null```) but this does not work consistently in many scenario's

### example

``` powershell
function Invoke-MyTool {
Start-DetailedLog 'myfile.log'
Write-Host 'Hello World'
Write-Verbose 'Hello underworld!
Stop-DetailedLog 'myfile.log'
}

Invoke-MyTool
# or perhaps 
# Invoke-MyTool -Verbose 
# either would be acceptable as long as the behaviour was defined
```

Screen output would be
```
Hello World
```

myfile.log would be 
```
Hello World
Hello underworld!
```

It would be nice to be able to have timestamps on each line in the log also

If this is possible to incorporate this functionality in to Start-Transcript then that would be great

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

In windows , Resource Monitor --> Network --> Listening Ports, it lists image(process), PID, address , port, protocol, firewall status. it's quite useful for user who use UI , but for user who use powershell to manage windows , the corresponding CMDLET is Get-NetTCPConnection ,  this doesn't display the image(process) name and firewall status , which is not so convenient ，someone may say the image name can be obtained via querying the displayed PID, but how about the firewall status ?

 In Linux , the similar command is ss -lnp.

Could someone do a native cmdlet for --"Resource Monitor -- Network -- Listening Ports" rather than require user to write his own powershell function to get the same info.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

attach a screenshot which is took from the resource monitor UI .
![ss-ln-via-powershell](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36788337/171804160-0c9808d0-1c27-4208-9392-c3ca16ed65f7.PNG)

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When running WindowsPowerShell-only cmdlets via WinPSCompat implicit and leveraging a RunspacePool (runspaces running in parallel), memory leaks + thread leaks will occur.

Consider the following snippet:
```powershell
$ScriptBlocks = @(
    "Get-WMIObject -Class Win32_Bios",
    "Get-WMIObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystemProduct",
    "Get-WMIObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystem",
    "Get-WMIObject -Class Win32_ComputerSystemProcessor",
    "Get-WMIObject -Class Win32_CurrentTime"
)
1..50 | ForEach-Object {
    $result = $ScriptBlocks | ForEach-Object -Parallel { & ([scriptblock]::Create($_)); } -ThrottleLimit 3 
    Write-Host $result.Count
    Start-Sleep -Seconds 10
}
```
Items to consider:
- A `ForEach-Object -Parallel` internally uses a runspace pool to orchestrate requests across multiple runspaces in parallel; This issue is also reproducible when a `RunspacePool` is used directly with `PowerShell` objects to run script blocks.
- `Get-WMIObject` is a WindowsPowerShell-only cmdlet, so its invocation will use the Windows PowerShell compatibility (WinPSCompat session) implicitly.


### Expected behavior
No memory leaks or thread leaks occur: PowerShell 7 is able to handle the implicit creation + disposal of the WinPSCompat session and corresponding remoteIpMoProxy_* stub modules automatically.


### Actual behavior
On the PowerShell script share above, Memory leaks + thread leaks occur:
- Threads are leaked (remain locked in `OutOfProcessClientSessionTransportManagerBase.ProcessMessageProc()`) 
- Memory leak of objects of OutOfProcessClientSessionTransportManager occur, since they usually are large objects referenced the call stack of the leaked threads. 
- remoteIpMoProxy_* folders in the temp folder of the current user keep being created but are not deleted.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\7> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.7
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.7
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22598
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

- Folders remoteIpMoProxy_* keep being added but not deleted.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52970903/171760088-001acb5c-f7d5-45f1-9327-6d0db358b203.png)

- Theads and overall memory of the Pwsh.exe process keeps increasing as the above script runs. This is a snapshot after running for just a few minutes:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52970903/171760650-943dd312-f70a-49a3-b036-cf2a11c268ba.png)

### Prerequisites

### Steps to reproduce

Related: 
* #4726
* Said issue argues that it's fundamentally problematic to allow executing scripts / executables by _wildcard patterns_, which is at the core of this issue too.

With a wildcard-based path that has _two or more_ matches:

* invocation fails with a misleading error message
* `Get-Command` reports no results, with or without `-All`

Note: Wildcard path `C:\WINDOWS\system32\find*.exe` matches _two_ executables, `find.exe` and `findstr.exe`.

```powershell
C:\WINDOWS\system32\find*.exe /?

Get-Command C:\WINDOWS\system32\find*.exe
```

### Expected behavior

Invocation:

A descriptive error message indicating the ambiguity of the call, due to _multiple_ executables matching.


`Get-Command`: 

_Both_ matches should be reported.


### Actual behavior

Invocation:

The error message misleadingly suggests that _no_ matching executable was found:

`... is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable
program. ...`

`Get-Command`: 

No output.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core v7.3.0-preview.4
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

These steps work on my machine (Windows 10 21H2), but probably won't be reproducible universally, otherwise this would be already reported. I'll be happy to give more information about my setup if necessary.

1. Install PowerShell v7.3.0-preview.2
2. Run `hyperfine 'pwsh -noprofile -nologo -c exit'` (or use any other command to measure command run time)
3. Install PowerShell v7.3.0-preview.3

### Expected behavior

Similar startup time for both versions.

PowerShell v7.3.0-preview.2
```console
$> hyperfine 'pwsh -noprofile -nologo -c exit' --runs 30
Benchmark 1: pwsh -noprofile -nologo -c exit
  Time (mean ± σ):     281.3 ms ±  18.1 ms    [User: 2.0 ms, System: 6.2 ms]
```


body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

In 7.2.4 and 7.3.0-Preview-4 I see the following for `get-help new-variable -Parameter scope`
```
-Scope <System.String>
    Specifies the scope of the new variable. The acceptable values for this parameter are:

    - `Global` - Variables created in the global scope are accessible everywhere in a PowerShell process. 
    - `Local` - The local scope refers to the current scope, this can be any scope depending on the context. 
    - `Script` - Variables created in the script scope are accessible only within the script file or module they are created in. 
    - `Private` - Variables created in the private scope cannot be accessed outside the scope they exist  in. 
```
(Although the markdown bullet points are not processed correctly) 
According to this private **IS** a scope.  

However, creating a variable with `-Scope Private` is not the same as `-Visibility Private` or `-Option Private`, and variables **can** be seen in other scopes 
```
PS>  new-variable -Name one -Value "111" -Scope Private -Force
PS>  $one
111
PS>  & {$one}  # NOT private
111 

PS>  new-variable -Name two -Value "222" -Visibility Private
PS>  $two  # Private from ourselves 
PermissionDenied: Cannot access the variable '$two' because it is a private variable.
PS>  & {$two} # but visible in the child scope
222

PS>  new-variable -Name three -Value "333" -Option Private
PS>  $three
333
PS>  & {$three}   # Not visible in the child scope

PS>
```

This behaviour mirrors what `about_scope` says 
```
  [!NOTE] PRIVATE is not a scope. It is an option that changes the  visibility of an item outside of the scope where the item is defined.
```

`Private` being an _option_, not a _scope_ and distinct from the _visibility_ setting, appears to be correct and the cmdlet help appears to be wrong.  


### Expected behavior

```console
Cmdlet help agrees with about and matches behaviour
```


### Actual behavior

```console
It doesn't
```


### Error details

```console
n/a
```

```powershell
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3

```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

> As a PowerShell script and module developer, I want to be able to use syntactic sugar for defining a switch statement that operates on an input variable based on that variable's object type, so that I can reduce the amount of boilerplate code used for this purpose.

I find myself needing to switch on object types primarily under two conditions: when I'm munging unreliable data and processing collections of non-alike objects (especially tokens from parsing some sort of AST).

Right now, there's really only two effective ways (that _I_ know of) to get this behavior:

1. Pass the object to act on to `switch` and then use a conditional check for each type you want to handle, specifying `$_ -is <type-to-handle>`. 
2. Call the **GetType** method in the input expression, place the types in parentheses as the values, and then reference the input variable (**not** `$_` or `$PSItem`) in the scriptblock.

### Conditional Validation

For this construction of the switch statement, you pass the object directly to `switch` and then use conditionals for each handled type, checking if `$_` is that type or not. You can then reference the current value by `$_`. This works for scalars and collections alike.

```powershell
function Get-SwitchedOutput {
  param($InputObject)
  
  switch ($InputObject) {
    ($_ -is [string])    { "I am a string! My value is: '$_'" }
    ($_ -is [hashtable]) { "I am a hash table! My value is: '$($_.Message)'" }
    default              { "I am a $($_.GetType())! I'm not currently handled. :(" }
  }
}

$ExampleInput = @{
  String  = 'Hello, friendo!'
  Hash    = @{ ID = 'Greeting' ; Message = 'ohai!' }
  Boolean = $true
}

Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.String
Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Hash
Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Boolean

Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Values
```

```output
I am a string! My value is: 'Hello, friendo!'

I am a hash table! My value is: 'ohai!'

I am a bool! I'm not currently handled. :(

I am a string! My value is: 'Hello, friendo!'
I am a hash table! My value is: 'ohai!'
I am a bool! I'm not currently handled. :(
```

For short or infrequent use, this is _okay_, but it means repeating conditional statements over and over; it can be a little messy.

### GetType Comparison

This option calls the **GetType()** method in the test expression itself, then has each type (wrapped in parentheses) as the conditional. In the action scriptblock for each matching type the actual object must be referenced; you can't use `$_` or `$PSItem` because that value is now a **RuntimeType** object. This prevents the switch from working on collections as input; the switch needs to be called in a `ForEach-Object` scriptblock or other looping construct that iterates over the items in the collection.

```powershell
function Get-SwitchedOutput {
  param($InputObject)
  
  switch ($InputObject.GetType()) {
    ([string])    { "I am a string! My value is: '$InputObject'" }
    ([hashtable]) { "I am a hash table! My value is: '$($InputObject.Message)'" }
    default       { "I am a $_! I'm not currently handled. :(" }
  }
}

$ExampleInput = @{
  String  = 'Hello, friendo!'
  Hash    = @{ ID = 'Greeting' ; Message = 'ohai!' }
  Boolean = $true
}

Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.String
Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Hash
Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Boolean

Get-SwitchedOutput -InputObject $ExampleInput.Values
```

```output
I am a string! My value is: 'Hello, friendo!'

I am a hash table! My value is: 'ohai!'

I am a bool! I'm not currently handled. :(

I am a System.Collections.Hashtable+ValueCollection, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=6.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e! I'm not currently handled. :(
```

This construction is more readable as long as you don't need to operate on collections; but if you do, it immediately becomes more complex. It also requires a referencing the value from the original variable instead of `$_` or `$PSItem`, which can be confusing (and possibly a little fraught).

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

In my experience, I read many more lines of code (especially if we include re-reads of the same line) than I write and I _suspect_ this is true for everyone. For cases where this behavior is needed, it would be preferable to rely on some syntactic sugar to make the code more readable.

Ideally, an implementation would allow this:

```powershell
switch -type ($InputObject) {
    [string]    { "I am a string! My value is: '$_'" }
    [hashtable] { "I am a hash table! My value is: '$($_.Message)'" }
    default     { "I am a $($_.GetType())! I'm not currently handled. :(" }
}
```

An implementation allowing that example block would, in my opinion, be clear, backwards compatible (because it relies on a new parameter for `switch`, not modifying existing behavior), and much more readable/maintainable.

Similar constructs exist in other languages, such as golang and ruby:

### Go

In Go, you can use a type assertion in a switch statement. This is roughly similar to the **GetType** option above. `item` in this code is the `inputObject` with the listed type asserted (so you can access properties and methods of that object, since go is strongly typed and the compiler gets angry if you make it guess).

```golang
switch item := inputObject.(type) {
case string:
	fmt.Printf("I am a string! My value is: '%s'\n", item)
case map[string]string:
	fmt.Printf("I am a hashtable! My value is: '%s'\n", item["Message"])
default:
	fmt.Printf("I am a %T! I'm not currently handled. :(\n", item)
}
```

### Ruby

In Ruby, you can have your case statement act on the type of the object without any special handling. This is the most similar to this feature request (though Ruby's implementation doesn't handle unwrapping collections for you, you'd need to put this in a recursive function - so in _practice_ it's somewhere between the desired implementation and the existing one).

```ruby
case inputObject
when String
  "I am a string! My value is: '#{inputObject}'"
when Hash
  "I am a hash table! My value is: '#{inputObject[:Message]}'"
else
  "I am a #{inputObject.class}! I'm not currently handled. :("
end
```

## Summary

While this feature request is for syntactic sugar, I think it would be a worthwhile improvement for readability and maintainability of code bases that have to handle unreliable data types or collections of mixed data types.

# PR Summary

Fix #17452

The changes in this PR update the behavior of `Out-File` and `Out-String` regarding the `RenderingOutput` setting to be the following:
- when the input object is pure string, these 2 cmdlets keep the string input unchanged regardless of the `RenderingOutput` setting
- when the input object needs to have formatting views applied to it, these 2 cmdlets remove escape sequences from the formatting output strings based on the `RenderingOutput` setting.

This change is a breaking change to these 2 cmdlets' existing behavior regarding `RenderingOutput`.

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

When I use Set-Clipboard to copy a password to the clipboard on Windows, I would like a way to prevent the password from being stored to the clipboard history and the cloud clipboard.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Implement a `-Sensitive` option

```PowerShell
(Import-Clixml “password.xml”).GetNetworkCredential().Password | Set-Clipboard -Sensitive
```

and use the `ExcludeClipboardContentFromMonitorProcessing` clipboard format documented in [Cloud Clipboard and Clipboard History Formats](https://docs.microsoft.com/windows/win32/dataxchg/clipboard-formats#cloud-clipboard-and-clipboard-history-formats).

title: Powershell wasm patch

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This happens in 7.3.0-preview.4, and all other 7.3 preview versions.
**This is a regression from both 7.0.x and 7.2.x (both are LTS versions).**

Content of the test file `try.ps1`: (Ansi escape sequence is used for color).
```
Read-Host -Prompt "[33mEnter your device code[0m"
```

Try replacing ``"`r`n"`` with ``"`n"`` for the content in the file and save it to another file:
```pwsh
(Get-Content .\try.ps1 -Raw).Replace("`r`n", "`n") > new.ps1
## Or, (Get-Content .\try.ps1 -Raw).Replace("`r`n", "`n")  | Out-File new.ps1
```

Now all Ansi escape sequences are lost in the content of `new.ps1`:
```
Read-Host -Prompt "Enter your device code"
```
---------------------------------------------------------------

`Set-Content` works as expected, which preserves the Ansi escape sequences.

```pwsh
(Get-Content .\try.ps1 -Raw).Replace("`r`n", "`n") | Set-Content new.ps1
```
---------------------------------------------------------------

Behavior in 7.0.11:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/170773178-9b3a660c-af15-4383-a0a2-9adc83dbdb3b.png)

Behavior in 7.2.2:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/170773256-eaa5cce9-1cee-4d6e-b135-3eb120150d0a.png)

-------------------------------------------

### Root cause and behavior proposal

The root cause of this regression is having `Host` to be the default value for `$PSStyle.OutputRendering`, which make the `Out-*` cmdlet to strip off escape sequences from the passed-in input.

- In 7.0.x, the `$PSStyle` feature is not there, so `Out-*` commands don't do anything special to Ansi escape sequences in the input.
- In 7.2.x, the default value for `$PSStyle.OutputRendering` is `Ansi`, so the behavior is unchanged without a user knowing about the `$PSStyle` feature.
- In 7.3, the default value is changed to `Host`, which makes `Out-*` cmdlets to always strip off escape sequences from the input, and hence the regression.

I understand the purpose of having `Host` option for `$PSStyle.OutputRendering` -- it's nice to have ANSI decorations in the formatting output when it's rendered on terminal, but when redirecting the formatting out like in `Get-Process > file`, the escape sequences in the formatting output becomes annoying. The `Host` option is to tell PowerShell to not keep ANSI decorations in case of redirection (essentially `Out-File`, and basically any `Out-*` cmdlets such as `Out-String`).

But for pure string input that doesn't really go through formatting, it doesn't seem right to remove the Ansi escape sequences, given that the formatting system doesn't add any to it. The `Out-*` should treat the pure string input as is, and only remove escape sequences when the input object actually goes through formatting.

So, the **proposal** is: option `Host` makes `Out-*` cmdlets remove escape sequences only if the input object actually goes through formatting within the `Out-*` cmdlets. For string input, `Out-*` cmdlet should not do anything special regarding Ansi escape sequences.

### Expected behavior

```console
The content in new.ps1 should be the same as in try.ps1, except that all "\r\n" characters are replaced with "\n".
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The escape sequences in the original file was removed during redirection.
```


### Error details

```console
N/A
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PS:24> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I can feel people saying "oh no, not another verb request" But bear with me. 

I've been playing with creating crescendo commands for terraform. 
Terraform has the concepts of     
**plan**  examine the desired state and current actual state and decide what needs to be done. 
**apply**  'Make it so' either by executing steps which were (optionally) saved at by a plan operation or planning steps on the fly. 

 This can be shoehorned into PowerShell verbs by making "plan" a noun instead of verb, so we can "create a New plan," instead of "planning a deployment". And we can "Deploy a configuration" (from a plan, or not).   
In fact doing what was prepared seems to fit existing verbs - if the authors of terraform had chosen, deploy,  import, merge,  publish, push, submit,  or update instead of "apply" no-one would have noticed, but there's nothing  to replace "plan"

There are other cases in data transformation, where there is a preliminary phase before data is imported/exported/saved/converted.  "Prepare" seems the most logical verb to me, right now, but there may be another which is just as suitable. 
 
 
 

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add a verb to the approved list.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Suggest add a option `[-Target] <String>` to support mount point in a PSDrive:

For example, I have two folder, and each has a module folder inside:
```
.\Code\Submodule1
    - Module1

.\Code\Submodule2
    - Module2
```

```powershell
New-PSDrive -Name "X" -Target "\" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root ".\Code\Submodule1"
New-PSDrive -Name "X" -Target "\" -PSProvider "FileSystem" -Root ".\Code\Submodule2"
```

With `[-Target] <String>` support and after above command, PSDrive `X` should be:
```
X:
    Module1
    Module2
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Have a directory that contains a period.  When a DirectoryInfo is retrieved from Get-Item, the BaseName property includes the period and text after while the Extension property is an empty string.  When a DirectoryInfo is retrieved from Get-ChildItem, both the BaseName and Extension properties both include the period and the text after.


```
$ pwsh.exe -noprofile
PowerShell 7.2.4
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation.

https://aka.ms/powershell
Type 'help' to get help.

PS C:\Temp> mkdir 'C:\Temp\FileName.zip\'

	Directory: C:\Temp

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
d----          2022-05-26    16:48                FileName.zip

PS C:\Temp> pushd 'C:\Temp'
PS C:\Temp> $fromGetItem = Get-Item -Path '.\FileName.zip\'
PS C:\Temp> $fromGetChildItem = (Get-ChildItem -Path .)[0]
PS C:\Temp> $fromGetItem | Select-Object -Property Name,BaseName,Extension | Format-List

Name      : FileName.zip
BaseName  : FileName.zip
Extension :


PS C:\Temp> $fromGetChildItem | Select-Object -Property Name,BaseName,Extension | Format-List

Name      : FileName.zip
BaseName  : FileName.zip
Extension : .zip


PS C:\Temp> $fromGetItem.GetType()

IsPublic IsSerial Name                                     BaseType
-------- -------- ----                                     --------
True     False    DirectoryInfo                            System.IO.FileSystemInfo

PS C:\Temp> $fromGetChildItem.GetType()

IsPublic IsSerial Name                                     BaseType
-------- -------- ----                                     --------
True     False    DirectoryInfo                            System.IO.FileSystemInfo
```

### Expected behavior

```console
I'd expect objects retrieved from either Get-Item or Get-ChildItem cmdlets to have consistent Name, BaseName, and Extension properties.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
When a DirectoryInfo is retrieved from Get-Item, the BaseName property includes the period and text after while the Extension property is an empty string.  When a DirectoryInfo is retrieved from Get-ChildItem, both the BaseName and Extension properties both include the period and the text after.
```

_No response_

```powershell

PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.4

Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user, I would expect Get-Command to mirror command discovery; if I can invoke a command (e.g., `uptime`) then I should be able to find the command pwsh is invoking with Get-Command.

However, `Get-Command uptime` returns no results, despite simply calling `uptime` ending up finding and calling `Get-Uptime`.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Get-Command should implement the same fallback behaviour used in command discovery; if no results are found and the command contains no verb, the `Get-` verb should be prepended to try to find the command in the same way command discovery normally would find the command.

title: Invoke-RestMethod strips Content-Type Header from supplied Headers with -SkipHeaderValidation

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

For **every** object, this is true:
```PowerShell
$InputObject.ToString -as [Func[String]]
```

But if I put that code in a function:
```PowerShell
filter ConvertTo-String {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param([Parameter(ValueFromPipeline)]$InputObject)
    if ($InputObject.ToString -as [Func[String]]) {
        $PSStyle.Foreground.Yellow + $InputObject.ToString()
    }
}
```

It's literally **never** true.

I had to add this:

```PowerShell
    elseif ($InputObject.psobject.BaseObject.ToString -as [Func[String]]) {
        $PSStyle.Foreground.Cyan + $InputObject.ToString()
    }
```

The weird thing is that `$InputObject.ToString.GetType() -eq $InputObject.psobject.BaseObject.ToString.GetType()` so I don't know why one is castable and the other is not.

For what it's worth, my original goal was to write some "duck typing" where I check for "ToPsMetadata" and "FromPsMetadata" and assume the object implements `IPSMetadataSerializable`:

```csharp
public interface IPsMetadataSerializable {
    string ToPsMetadata();
    void FromPsMetadata(string Metadata);
}
```

### Expected behavior

```console
`$Object.ToString -as [Func[String]]` should always return the delegate
```


### Actual behavior

```console
If the `$Object` is a PSObject, the PSMethodInfo can't be cast to the delegate
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PSVersion                      7.2.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22621
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
